content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define "private fund" as an issuer exempt from being an investment company under certain sections, and "foreign private fund adviser" as an adviser with no US office, fewer than 15 US clients, and assets under management in the US below a specified amount. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define a "private fund" as an issuer exempt from being an investment company under certain sections. A "foreign private fund adviser" is defined as an adviser with no US office, fewer than 15 US clients, and assets under management in the US below a specified amount. The amendment also specifies criteria for entities exempt from registration as an investment adviser in the US. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF PRIVATE ADVISER EXEMPTION; LIMITED EXEMPTION FOR FOREIGN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS; LIMITED INTRASTATE EXEMPTION. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. Additionally, the amendment specifies that small business investment companies and entities receiving funding from the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 are exempt from certain regulations. Entities eligible for exemption from certain regulations include those that have received notice from the Small Business Administration to qualify for a license, or applicants related to licensed small business investment companies who have applied for another license that is pending. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require investment advisers to maintain records and file reports regarding private funds advised by them for the protection of investors and assessment of systemic risk. The Commission can share this information with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and other entities responsible for systemic risk. Investment advisers must maintain records and file reports for private funds they advise, including information on assets under management, leverage, counterparty credit risk exposures, trading positions, and other relevant data determined by the Commission in consultation with the Federal Reserve. The Commission may require private fund advisers to report additional information as necessary for the public interest and systemic risk assessment. Registered investment advisers must maintain records of private funds for specified periods for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The Commission may conduct periodic examinations of private fund records maintained by registered investment advisers. Advisers must provide copies of records upon request. The Commission shares information with the Federal Reserve and other entities for systemic risk assessment. The Commission may require investment advisers to provide reports and information for assessing systemic risk of private funds. The information obtained will be kept confidential. Investment advisers must disclose certain private fund information to investors and others as prescribed by the Commission. The Commission is not required to disclose reports or information filed under this subsection, except to Congress, other federal agencies, or courts. This paragraph is considered a statute under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to eliminate a disclosure provision and provide exemptions and reporting requirements for venture capital fund advisers and certain private fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide exemptions and reporting requirements for private fund advisers with assets under management below $150,000,000. Additionally, regulations are prescribed for mid-sized private fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide exemptions and reporting requirements for private fund advisers with assets under $150,000,000. The Commission will consider size, governance, and investment strategy of mid-sized private funds to assess systemic risk and establish registration and examination procedures based on the level of risk. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make rules and regulations, classify persons and matters based on various criteria, prescribe different requirements, and assign different meanings to terms. The Commission is granted authority to make rules and regulations, classify persons and matters, and assign meanings to terms. The Commission, along with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, will establish rules for reports to be filed by investment advisers registered under both the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. SEC. 9. GAO STUDY. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to assess the costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period from the enactment date. The Securities and Exchange Commission will establish rules allowing advisers to register before the deadline. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. The Commission will adjust dollar amount tests for inflation every 5 years. Adjustments not multiples of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
